thread_structure: Your event is in 72 hours and you just realized you need a tux. Don't panic. I've handled 1000+ emergencies. Here's the exact playbook:
Hour 1: Call, don't email. Explain the situation. Most shops keep emergency inventory. Ask for 'rush service' - yes, it costs more. Worth it.
Hour 2: Know your measurements or be ready to come in IMMEDIATELY. Chest, waist, inseam, neck, sleeve. Have them written down.
Hour 3: Be flexible on style. You're not getting the velvet Gucci tux. You're getting what fits and looks good. Check your ego.
Hour 4-24: First fitting. Try EVERYTHING on. Walk, sit, raise your arms. Don't say 'it's fine' if it's not. Alterations happen now or never.
Hour 24-48: Pick up. Try it on again in the store. Bring your shoes. Bring your shirt. Make sure studs/cufflinks/bow tie are included.
Hour 48-72: Keep the receipt, keep the shop's number saved. If anything goes wrong day-of, you need to reach them instantly.
Real talk: Rush fees range from $50-200 depending on the shop. It's cheaper than missing the event or looking like a slob.
Pro tip: Most formal wear emergencies happen because someone procrastinated. Set a phone reminder 2 weeks before ANY formal event.

twitter_content_templates.hook_tweet: Prom moms: Your son will tell you 'any tux is fine' and then complain about the photos for 10 years. Here are the 7 non-negotiables:
thread_structure: Prom moms: Your son will tell you 'any tux is fine' and then complain about the photos for 10 years. Here are the 7 non-negotiables:
1. The fit matters MORE than the style. A $200 tux that fits perfectly beats a $600 designer tux that's too big. Get the alterations.
2. Match the date's dress color with accessories, not the whole tux. Bow tie, vest, or pocket square. Never a colored tux jacket. Never.
3. Make him try on the shoes. Tux shoes are different from sneakers. He needs to walk around the store. Yes, he'll hate this. Do it anyway.
4. Book the fitting 6-8 weeks out. Earlier if it's April/May (peak prom season). Last-minute = limited selection + stress.
5. Get the insurance/damage waiver. Teenage boys + white shirts + punch bowls = inevitable disaster. $15 insurance saves $300 replacement.
6. Pick-up should be 2-3 days before prom, not day-of. Gives you time to fix problems. And there WILL be problems.
7. Take photos in the tux at the shop. If something's wrong, you catch it now. Not in the limo. Not at dinner. Now.
Bonus: The tux should make him feel confident, not like he's playing dress-up. If he feels ridiculous, try a different style.
